children: Intestinal features of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP). Duodenal adenomas can also develop, especially involving the ampulla of Vater, and evolve into adenocarcinoma (
). If a patient with FAP has had surgery and has an ileorectal anastomosis, rectal polyps can develop in the remaining rectum (
). Numerous fundic gland polyps of the stomach can develop in FAP; these polyps have minimal malignant potential but can obscure the presence of gastric adenomas (
